Asked about Chris Huhne 's comments, the prime minister's spokesman said today: The position at the present time is that the Crown Prosecution Service are carrying out an assessment of the information that is held by the Metropolitan police. That process is under way and it is up to the CPS to make a decision on their assessment.`` The prime minister's position is that if there are allegations of illegal behaviour, then those allegations need to be taken very seriously, but in all cases it is a matter for the police and the CPS. executive chairman,`` a lot of my time'' will be devoted to dealing with regulators and other government officials, Eric Schmidt said.`` We've got very complicated government issues,'' he said, adding that we move quickly, and we tend to be disruptive at scale. European Union officials opened a formal antitrust probe last year into Google search results, while in China the company opted to shut down its mainland search engine rather than censor results for user queries.
